incidents.name: Google Safe Browsing flag as malware

incident_updates.body: Success! Google Safe Browsing has removed the malware flag from rubygems.org. Special thanks are owed to everyone who connected us to the Chrome and Safe Browsing teams, and the team members who assisted in clearing this up.
We have heard that our appeal has successfully been escalated within the Google Safe Browsing team, and they are working to resolve things.

Google Safe Browsing has flagged the entire rubygems.org domain as malware, impacting all users of the Chrome, Safari, and Firefox browser.

The underlying issue appears to be an incorrect malware flag applied to all versions of a gem from the metasploit family. In our investigation we’ve identified that the same library is also available from GitHub and many Linux and BSD distro packages. We continue investigating, sharing information and working with Google to resolve this as soon as possible.

For the time being, there are no other issues: the website can be accessed as normal if you bypass the warning. Gem downloads and pushes continue working as normal.

components.name: Application

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
Our CDN provider has applied a fix and over the last few minutes we saw traffic levels and errors return to normal.
Our CDN partner has identified the issue and a fix is being implemented.
The elevated 503 and 502 errors seem to be because of Fastly's ongoing incident. We are following along at https://status.fastly.com/incidents/vpk0ssybt3bj.
We're experiencing an elevated level of errors and are currently looking into the issue.

We have received reports of some gems not being able to be installed. We have identified the issue and we are working on resolving it. Gems published before 2015-08-23 may be unlisted on the versions API.

affected_components.name: No components were affected by this update.

incident_updates.body: We receive reports that a major ISP had a complete outage between the United States and Europe for about 20 minutes at 14:45 UTC.

affected_components.name: No components were affected by this update.

incident_updates.body: Our upstream provider has implemented a fix and we are monitoring the results. We are also seeing reports of general internet issues in Europe. We will post more information as we get it.

affected_components.name: No components were affected by this update.

incident_updates.body: We are aware of reports that services are unavailable in some regions. We're looking into it now!

affected_components.name: No components were affected by this update.

incident_updates.body:
We received reports of legacy software being unable to access RubyGems.org. Specifically anyone using TLS 1.1. This is common on older operating systems like Ubuntu Precise 12.04.

We quickly realized that our CDN provider had disabled TLS 1.1 today due to a previously announced deprecation of TLS 1.1. Unfortunately we hadn't taken steps to avoid this action today. Once we realized what had happened we migrated back to a configuration that allowed TLS 1.1.

I'm sorry if this impacted you today. Everything should be working again now. If you are still having issues please submit a help ticket.

The migration today is a short term change, and in the future we will be permanently disabling support for TLS 1.1. We will announce these dates.

affected_components.name: No components were affected by this update.

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We have identified the problem and deployed a fix.

We are aware that some newly pushed gems are not able to be installed when the dependency API is used. This is used by most versions of bundler and RubyGems. Our team is looking into it. Sorry for the inconvenience – we’ll have a solution for this soon!
The dependency API has been stable, answering all requests, for about two hours. We'll keep an eye on it, but everything seems resolved for now.

Service has been restored. After many infrastructure, configuration, and code changes today we have found the problem. The dependency API should be returning results in a reasonable time with no errors now. We're continuing to monitor things.

We're aware of intermittent errors on the dependency api. We saw an increase in traffic yesterday and the API was having trouble responding in a timely manner. We've made several changes to the service in the last 24 hours to reduce the error rates. Our failures are down but we are still seeing some requests fail with HTTP 500 errors.

We're working to fix the remaining errors, but in the meantime you can work around this by running: `bundle install --full-index`.
Error rates have returned to normal. Everything should be working now.
Our provider is reporting that service is returning to normal. We're still seeing higher than normal error rates so we are continuing to monitor closely.
Our CDN provider is experiencing an outage right now. Gem installs might not be working in some regions. We'll update when we know more.
High load on our database is causing errors right now.
